courseDescription: An introduction to essential themes and means of visual communication in the fine arts with an emphasis on studio experience in techniques from the different disciplines in studio art.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Team coordination in studio art projects

courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College.  A special honors section of ARTS 122A.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Providing and receiving constructive feedback on artwork
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Creative problem solving in art projects

courseDescription: An introduction to pictorial design via an intensive study of the elements and  principles of art and design and Gestalt Theory. These fundamental ideas are reinforced as color theory principles are introduced, such as: additive and subtractive color systems, color interaction, and harmonies as well as the phenomenon of simultaneous contrast.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding elements and principles of art and design
Knowledge of additive and subtractive color systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing color combinations for effective design

courseDescription: A basic course examining the relation of form and structure in a three-dimensional environment.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of material properties in 3D design
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with team members on design projects
Receiving and incorporating feedback on design work
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of form and structure in 3D design
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing project timelines for 3D design projects
Delegating tasks within a design team
Taking initiative in proposing new design ideas

courseDescription: This course provides students an overview of the options, methods, and strategies by which modern and contemporary artists operate. One of the primary learning outcomes is for students to be conversant with the discourse and ideas that they have inherited as artists, designers, and scholars in the 21st century in order to enrich their own creative practices.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project planning and execution in art

courseDescription: Introduction to conceptual, technical and historical aspects of photography as a creative medium using digital technology.  Technical areas covered include camera use, digital image processing, and digital printing.  Class time is divided between demonstrations of applicable skills, in class work time, lectures and critiques.

This course is structured to provide instruction to glass forming, balanced with the history, criticism, and aesthetics of glass art.  It is a basic course in the techniques of glassblowing, flameworking, kiln forming and coldworking, taught through a series of hands-on projects. Lectures, demonstrations, and critiques encourage students to consider both the technical and conceptual manifestations of this material. In addition, the Chrysler Museum’s extensive contemporary and historical glass collection and interaction with visiting and resident glass artists will be utilized.  The course allows students of all skill levels to learn new techniques to advance Io a higher level of art production.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interaction with visiting and resident artists
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of glass art concepts

courseDescription: An intensive studio course that fosters observational and visualization skills through a comprehensive exploration of composition, linear perspective, and sighting and measuring techniques. These principles are executed by utilizing line and value with a variety of media including graphite, charcoal, and ink. Investigations of the discipline's historic and contemporary dimensions support the course objectives.
Technical and Digital Skills: Utilization of graphite, charcoal, and ink media
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers in studio setting

courseDescription: An observational painting course that serves as an introduction to the fundamental concepts and competencies of oil painting. Primary emphasis is on composition, accuracy of color mixing, description of form and space as well as paint application techniques.
An introduction to basic relief printing techniques including woodcut, linocut, letterpress, and collograph.

A basic introduction to the aesthetic and conceptual possibilities of print media, focusing primarily on Intaglio and Relief printing techniques. Studio projects and demonstrations will be supplemented with lectures and readings exploring the significance of print to contemporary artists.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in discussions on print significance
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing aesthetic possibilities of print media
Evaluating conceptual aspects of print projects

courseDescription: A basic introduction to the aesthetic and conceptual possibilities of print media, focusing primarily on Screenprinting and Lithography. Studio projects and demonstrations will be supplemented with lectures and readings exploring the significance of print to contemporary artists.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a studio setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of different print techniques on artwork

courseTitle: Print I: Letterpress and Book Arts
courseDescription: A basic introduction to the aesthetic and conceptual possibilities of print media, focusing primarily on Letterpress and Book Arts. Studio projects and demonstrations will be supplemented with lectures and readings exploring the significance of print to contemporary artists.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a studio setting
Collaboration with peers on print projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experimenting with different print materials for optimal results
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on the significance of print media in art

courseDescription: Conceptual thinking in three dimensions; the development of visual capacity and spatial sense through direct experience in materials.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Designing sculptures from concept to completion

courseDescription: A studio core course designed as an introduction to ceramics.  Students will explore functional and sculptural techniques through handbuilding and wheel-throwing, as well as basic claybody, glaze and firing theory.  Students will also develop a basic understanding of the historical and cultural aspects of ceramics.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solving technical challenges in ceramic creation
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively in studio work

courseDescription: This course is an introduction to the Macintosh operating system, design industry-standard software programs, and technical applications to visual arts and design production. The course provides an overview of Adobe software programs (Photoshop, Illustrator, InDesign) and techniques for bitmap and vector image creation as well as page layout as used in print design and digital media development.
Technical and Digital Skills: Bitmap and vector image creation techniques
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in visual arts and design production

courseDescription: An introduction to various looms, tools, materials and techniques used in weaving and fabric dyeing; individual design projects.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of various looms and tools
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for individual design projects

courseDescription: This course is an introduction to the fundamentals of design and metal fabrication techniques for both jewelry and small objects. Working with precious and non-precious metals, students will learn traditional techniques including sawing, filing, cold connections, soldering, and polishing. A series of structured assignments guide students as they transform their ideas into finished works. Solutions for projects are open to enable the student to explore their own aesthetic while mastering the outlined material. Lectures on historical, contemporary and cultural examples of jewelry inform and inspire students' work.

An introductory studio art course for non-art majors. The course is designed to acquaint students with industry standard graphic software, the Macintosh operating system, and its application to digital graphics production. It includes an overview of computer hardware and software used for visual communication.
Technical and Digital Skills: Proficiency in industry standard graphic software
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of visual communication elements
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in digital graphics production
Team coordination for visual communication projects

courseDescription: This course encourages the refinement of technical skills as well as emphasizing the critical framework in which to place photographic imagery.  Assignments will challenge students to think creatively and develop their unique perspective.  Reading, research, and discussion introduce students to the major photographic movements that have shaped current theory.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in discussions about photographic theory
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing a critical framework for photography

courseDescription: This class explores controlled lighting for photography both inside and outside the studio. Emphasis is placed on exploring photographic concepts and the creative application of lighting technique and style both inside the studio and on location. Students will also investigate ways to communicate ideas through strong photographic imagery and how photography shapes and influences society through class readings and discussion.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Providing clear directions to models or clients during photoshoots
Collaborating with other photographers or assistants on set
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Troubleshooting lighting issues during a photoshoot
Analyzing different lighting setups to achieve desired effects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing a team of assistants during a photoshoot
Planning and coordinating multiple shoots in different locations

courseDescription: This course will focus on alternative as well as conventional techniques of the black and white darkroom. The class will approach image making with a focus on experimentation. Techniques covered will include photograms, pinhole photography, Van Dyke brown and gelatin silver prints. In addition to production of images, an early history of photography, beginning with the camera obscura, will be discussed. Class sessions will be divided into lecture/slide presentations, critique of students' work, demonstrations, and open lab time. Students will create a final portfolio to be reviewed as a class at the end of the semester.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Giving and receiving constructive criticism during critiques
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experimenting with different darkroom techniques to achieve desired effects
Analyzing historical context of early photography methods
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Creating and organizing a final portfolio for class review

courseDescription: This course is structured to provide instruction to glass forming, balanced with the history, criticism, and aesthetics of glass art.  It is an intermediate course in the techniques of glassblowing, flame working, and coldworking, taught through a series of hands-on projects. Lectures, demonstrations, and critiques will encourage students to consider both the technical and conceptual manifestations of this material.  In addition, the Chrysler Museum’s extensive contemporary and historical glass collection and interaction with visiting and resident glass artists will be utilized.  The course allows students of intermediate levels to learn new techniques to advance to a higher level of art production.

This is an intensive studio course that builds on the perceptual and technical skills developed in ARTS 231. Using a variety of media including ink, charcoal, graphite, and chalk pastels, initial coursework will act as a review of direct observational drawing skills with an introduction to the formal optics of color perception and interaction through the framework of drawing. Students will begin exploring the expressive potential of drawing through thematically-driven projects during the second half of the semester.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Sharing and receiving feedback on artwork
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experimenting with different drawing media to achieve desired effects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Providing guidance and feedback to peers on their artwork

courseDescription: An intensive studio course that builds on the perceptual and technical skills developed in ARTS 241. Coursework includes a review and expansion of direct observational painting skills with exploration into the expressive potential of painting through thematically-driven projects.
Technical and Digital Skills: Exploration of expressive potential in painting

courseDescription: This course serves to expose students to various techniques in contemporary abstraction. Students explore a range of strategies for producing both objective and non-objective abstract work using drawing and/or painting media.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Providing constructive feedback on abstract art
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effectiveness of abstract strategies

courseDescription: Further investigation of chosen print technique (screenprint, lithography, relief, or intaglio) with special attention to the implementation of color.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Color selection and mixing for printmaking
Experimentation with different techniques to achieve desired results

courseDescription: Students investigate the integration of traditional print media with digital prints, photographic techniques, and rapid prototyping technologies. Readings and discussions will explore the relationship between analog and digital media. Students choose a conceptual theme that will guide their work throughout the semester.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of traditional print media with digital prints
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing relationship between analog and digital media
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading project development based on chosen theme
Managing time effectively for project completion

courseDescription: Students focus on a single print medium from Print I (Intaglio, Relief, Screenprint, Lithography, or Letterpress) for intensive study. Use of color, registration, and alternative techniques will be emphasized within a given medium. Students choose a conceptual theme that will guide their work throughout the semester.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Feedback incorporation from peers and instructors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation of techniques to fit conceptual theme
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project planning and execution based on chosen theme

courseDescription: Investigation involves the combination of various materials and construction techniques. Each student will improve their skills in fabrication to execute their research and concepts in object making and installation.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with other artists on installations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of material choices for artistic expression

courseDescription: This course is an introduction to the use of clay, also known as ceramics. It includes clay forming with pinch pots, slabs, coils and pottery wheels.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively for project deadlines

courseDescription: Students will explore functional and sculptural techniques through handbuilding and wheel-throwing, as well as basic claybody, glaze and firing theory. Students will also develop a basic understanding of the historical and cultural aspects of ceramics.  The class includes glaze chemistry, firing procedures, ceramic history and contemporary ceramics.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing historical and cultural aspects of ceramics

courseDescription: A structured research experience, under the supervision of an art department faculty member. A paper evaluating/analyzing the research, a log of research progress, and satisfactory evaluation by the supervising faculty are required.

Extracurricular activities may be approved for credit based on objectives, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and the student prior to the semester in which the activity is to take place.  Such credit is subject to review by the provost.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Establishing objectives and criteria for activities, formal communication with department and students, review procedures with provost
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of activity objectives, criteria, and evaluative procedures
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Setting up and managing extracurricular activities, leadership in coordinating with department and students, formal review process with provost

courseDescription: Extracurricular activities may be approved for credit based on objectives, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and the student prior to the semester in which the activity is to take place.  Such credit is subject to review by the provost.
Technical and Digital Skills: Goal setting and planning for extracurricular activities
Documentation and progress tracking for activities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation to unexpected challenges during activities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and managing a team for extracurricular projects
Delegating tasks efficiently within a group

courseDescription: An overview of techniques related to pattern drafting, advanced loom and off-loom weaving, and fabric painting.

This course will expand upon the fundamentals of design and metal fabrication techniques for jewelry. Working with precious and non-precious metals, students will learn traditional techniques including casting, stone setting and production processes. A series of structured assignments guide students as they transform their ideas into finished works. Solutions for projects are open to enable the student to explore their own aesthetic while mastering the outlined material. Lectures on historical, contemporary and cultural examples of jewelry inform and inspire students' work.
This course offers an introduction to the basic tools, materials and techniques used in forging, forming, hardening and tempering steel.  Exploration of form and process in working metal.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating techniques to others in the field
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing work processes in a forge

courseDescription: This course will expand upon the fundamentals of design and metal fabrication techniques for small objects. Working with precious and non-precious metals, students learn traditional techniques including chase and repousse, raising and forming. A series of structured assignments guide students as they transform their ideas into finished works. Solutions for projects are open to enable the student to explore their own aesthetic while mastering the outlined material. Lectures on historical, contemporary and cultural examples of metalsmithing inform and inspire students' work.
Technical and Digital Skills: Working with precious and non-precious metals
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Receiving and giving feedback on metalwork projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical and contemporary examples of metalsmithing
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on metalsmithing techniques

courseDescription: A study of selected topics designed for non majors, or for elective credit within a major.  These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

This is the capstone class for all students in the BFA program (except students in the graphic design concentration take ARTS 401). Focusing on the development and articulation of aesthetic vision and studio practice, students will identify key ideas and sources for their work. They will also clarify their methods and concepts to create a finished, exhibition quality project. The class also addresses professional installation, promotion, and documentation of finished work, culminating with an exhibition.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying key ideas and sources for work

courseDescription: The course focuses on the photographic series examining reportage and contemporary narrative.  Students will work on developing a fully conceived photographic series on a theme developed through guided individual research.  Reading and discussion will provide students a critical framework in which to place their photographic imagery.

The first of a two-semester sequence of concentrated individual work.  Students will identify a topic and create a complete body of work culminating in the senior show, ARTS 400.  Lectures, readings, discussion, critique, and field trips to develop the articulation of ideas and the clarification of purpose.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Giving and receiving constructive feedback on photos
Participation in group discussions and critiques
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Troubleshooting equipment issues during photo shoots
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating group field trips for photography opportunities
Taking initiative in exploring new photography techniques

courseDescription: This is the second in a two-semester sequence of concentrated individual work culminating in the senior show.  Through readings, discussion, critiques, field trips, and intense individual work, students will compile a body of work realizing their personal vision and articulate their ideas through the crafting of an artist statement.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing a cohesive body of work
Leading discussions and critiques in class

courseDescription: This course is structured to provide instruction to glass forming, balanced with the history, criticism, and aesthetics of glass art.  It is an advanced course in the techniques of glassblowing and flame working. Lectures, demonstrations, and critiques will encourage students to consider both the technical and conceptual manifestations of this material.  In addition, the Chrysler Museum’s extensive contemporary and historical glass collection and interaction with visiting and resident glass artists will be utilized.  The course allows students to learn new techniques to advance to a higher level of art production.

Further concentration on conceptual content and drawing skills, development of individual body of work exploring preferred concepts, subject matter, techniques, and media.  May be repeated for credit.
A study of visually important aspects of the structural, skeletal and muscular systems of the body.  Anatomical study will be related to drawing from the live model.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of structural, skeletal, and muscular systems
Ability to analyze anatomical details in live models
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with live models for accurate representation
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying key anatomical features for drawing
Analyzing different body structures for drawing purposes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively during live drawing sessions
Providing guidance to peers on anatomical drawing techniques

courseDescription: This course places the emphasis on advanced composition using the figure as the central theme.  The figure's expressive potential, along with a study of historical responses to figure drawing, will be examined in depth.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Critique and feedback on figure compositions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpreting and applying historical figure drawing styles
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing complex figure compositions

courseDescription: An intensive studio course that builds upon skills developed in ARTS 331 and ARTS 341. Students pursue various approaches to the development of pictorial space and investigate the connection between formal decision making, media use, and individual expression within their work.

Students develop an individual body of work exploring preferred concepts, subject matter, techniques, and media in close consultation with faculty. Written proposal by students required at registration.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with faculty for consultation
Articulating concepts and ideas in written proposals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experimenting with new techniques and approaches
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Taking initiative in exploring preferred concepts and subject matters

courseTitle: Hybrid Approaches to Painting and Drawing
courseDescription: This course emphasizes hybrid approaches to contemporary drawing and painting including the integration of digital processes into studio practice and production. Students will be introduced to various applications and techniques regularly used in contemporary painting and drawing, including generating digital imagery, diorama construction and image compositing. Traditional and nontraditional media and subjects may be used to assist in the fulfillment of students’ analytical and expressive intentions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using various digital applications for drawing and painting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experimenting with different media to achieve desired effects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing projects in various media
Managing time effectively to meet project deadlines

courseDescription: Students create a body of personal work based on their research and interests. Readings, discussion, and presentations situate students’ practice within contemporary print discourses.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of printmaking tools and equipment
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Providing constructive feedback on peers' work
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting traditional printmaking techniques to modern contexts
Experimenting with different printmaking processes to achieve desired outcomes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group discussions on printmaking concepts
Organizing and curating a final exhibition of personal work

courseDescription: A visual and literary investigation of language and wordplay using foundry and wood type and a Vandercook SP-20 proofing press.  Projects include expressive printed impressions of personal poetry and song lyric, political rant, and broadsides for entertainment or proselytizing.  A theme group project, such as a folio or a bound book, is usually assigned.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of typography and design principles
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Providing constructive feedback on printed work
Presenting and explaining design choices to peers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experimenting with different ink and paper combinations for desired results
Adapting designs to fit printing constraints
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and coordinating group project timelines
Supervising and guiding team members in project execution
Managing resources effectively for printmaking projects

courseDescription: This course covers both theoretical and practical concerns within contemporary 2D art (painting, drawing, print. A combination of reading, writing, and critique develop and deepen the trajectory of students' creative practice.
Experimental work reflecting individual initiative and attitude.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Receiving and providing constructive feedback on art pieces
Collaborating with other artists on projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of one's own work
Troubleshooting technical challenges in sculpting materials
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing a sculpture project timeline
Leading a group project in the studio

courseDescription: An advanced course in the science and art of ceramics.  Students will engage in guided independent research, developing their own direction by investigating clay bodies, glazes, firing methods and contemporary ceramic art.

Assemblage combines elements of various art and non-art media and materials. Lectures will be comprised of presentations about relevant artists, gallery and studio visits, and critiques.  Studio time allows students to explore personal directions in the medium.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of art pieces and techniques

courseDescription: This class is designed to initiate students from both studio art and non-studio backgrounds to the study of art therapy. It examines the history of art therapy in the United States, introduces the Expressive Therapies Continuum (ETC), and explores the application of art therapy techniques and their underlying rationales.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with clients through art
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing underlying rationales of art therapy techniques
Adapting techniques to individual client needs

courseDescription: The book as a work of art.  Lecture will explore historical and technical aspects of book design and production.  Studio work will be devoted to the production of a series of books involving page design, paper selection, printing and binding.
Advanced work in pattern drafting, loom techniques, off-loom weaving and fabric painting.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing fabric painting techniques for improvement

courseDescription: This course offers further exploration and concentration on jewelry and metalsmithing techniques. Through readings, discussions, self-directed and self-determined projects, students will explore new methods and content to develop an individual body of work. Additional emphasis will be placed on developing supplemental portfolio materials. May be repeated once for credit.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of individual body of work
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of new methods and content

courseDescription: An exploration of concepts and techniques in wood sculpture and furniture design and fabrication.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying design flaws and proposing solutions
Analyzing ergonomic considerations in furniture design
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team in furniture fabrication tasks
Time management for meeting project deadlines

courseDescription: This course offers further exploration and concentration on jewelry and metalsmithing techniques. Through readings, discussions, self-directed and self-determined projects, students will explore new methods and content to develop an individual body of work. Additional emphasis will be placed on developing supplemental portfolio materials. May be repeated for credit once.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Independent work ethic for self-directed projects

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on studio projects of mutual interest.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Giving and receiving constructive feedback on artwork
Collaborating with peers on art projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experimenting with different art mediums to achieve desired effects
Analyzing and interpreting artistic concepts and styles
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing individual art projects
Leading group discussions on art topics

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Studio Topics
courseDescription: Independent investigation of a subject to be selected under the advisement of the instructor.  Conferences, papers, field trips, portfolios, or exhibitions as appropriate.

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Studio Topics
courseDescription: Independent investigation of a subject to be selected under the advisement of the instructor.  Conferences, papers, field trips, portfolios, or exhibitions as appropriate.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in selecting and advising on topics

courseDescription: The first of a two-semester sequence of concentrated individual work.   Students will identify a topic and create a complete body of work.  Lectures, readings, discussion, critique, and field trips to develop the articulation of ideas and the clarification of purpose.
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning a complete body of work

courseDescription: This is the second in a two-semester  sequence of concentrated individual work. Through readings, discussion, critiques, field trips, and intense individual work, students will compile a body of work realizing their personal vision and articulate their ideas through the crafting of an artist statement.
Technical and Digital Skills: Digital camera operation and settings mastery
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Giving and receiving constructive feedback during critiques
Articulating personal vision through artist statement
Participating in discussions on photography concepts and techniques
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and critiquing own work for improvement
Adapting to different shooting conditions and adjusting camera settings accordingly
Identifying and solving technical issues during photo shoots
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizing personal photo projects
Leading and facilitating group discussions on photography topics
Managing time effectively for field trips and individual work

courseDescription: Further concentration on conceptual content and drawing skills, development of individual body of work exploring preferred concepts, subject matter, techniques, and media.  May be repeated for credit.
A study of visually important aspects of the structural, skeletal and muscular systems of the body.  Anatomical study will be related to drawing from the live model.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of skeletal and muscular systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers for feedback and critique
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying proportions and relationships in figure drawing
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for figure drawing sessions

courseDescription: This course places the emphasis on advanced composition using the figure as the central theme.  The figure's expressive potential, along with a study of historical responses to figure drawing, will be examined in depth.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital tools for figure drawing
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with models and peers in figure drawing sessions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing historical figure drawing styles and responses
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing artistic projects related to figure drawing

courseDescription: Students develop an individual body of work exploring preferred concepts, subject matter, techniques, and media in close consultation with faculty. Written proposal by students required at registration.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding different painting media (e.g., canvas, paper)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with faculty for consultation
Receiving and providing constructive feedback on artwork
Collaborating with peers on art projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experimenting with new techniques to solve artistic challenges
Analyzing and critiquing own work for improvement
Adapting to unexpected issues during the creative process
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing individual art projects
Managing time effectively to meet project deadlines
Providing guidance to peers in group projects

courseDescription: Experimental work in selected print media.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Giving and receiving constructive feedback on artwork
Collaborating with other artists on projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experimenting with new techniques to achieve desired effects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively to complete projects
Providing guidance to peers on printmaking processes

courseDescription: Experimental work reflecting individual initiative and attitude.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of materials like clay, stone, metal, etc.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Giving and receiving constructive feedback on artwork
Collaborating with other artists on projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing time effectively for project completion
Guiding and mentoring other aspiring sculptors

courseDescription: An advanced course in the science and art of ceramics.  Students will engage in guided independent research, developing their own direction by investigating clay bodies, glazes, firing methods and contemporary ceramic art.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation of ceramic research findings
Collaboration with peers on ceramic projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Experiment design for ceramic material testing
Analysis of contemporary ceramic art trends
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for independent research in ceramics
Guiding peers in ceramic techniques and processes

courseDescription: Assemblage combines elements of various art and non-art media and materials. Lectures will be comprised of presentations about relevant artists, gallery and studio visits, and critiques.  Studio time allows students to explore personal directions in the medium.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Engaging in gallery and studio visits
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Creative problem-solving in mixed media art
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on relevant artists and media

courseDescription: This class is designed to initiate students from both studio art and non-studio backgrounds to the study of art therapy. It examines the history of art therapy in the United States, introduces the Expressive Therapies Continuum (ETC), and explores the application of art therapy techniques and their underlying rationales.
Technical and Digital Skills: Applying art therapy principles in practice
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the underlying rationales of art therapy techniques
Adapting therapy methods to individual needs

courseDescription: The book as a work of art.  Lecture will explore historical and technical aspects of book design and production.  Studio work will be devoted to the production of a series of books involving page design, paper selection, printing and binding.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with team members on book production
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing different paper qualities for optimal book design
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team in the creation of a series of books

courseDescription: Advanced work in pattern drafting, loom techniques, off-loom weaving and fabric painting.

This course offers further exploration and concentration on jewelry and metalsmithing techniques. Through readings, discussions, self-directed and self-determined projects, students will explore new methods and content to develop an individual body of work. Additional emphasis will be placed on developing supplemental portfolio materials. May be repeated once for credit.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of new methods and content

courseDescription: This course offers further exploration and concentration on jewelry and metalsmithing techniques. Through readings, discussions, self-directed and self-determined projects, students will explore new methods and content to develop an individual body of work. Additional emphasis will be placed on developing supplemental portfolio materials. May be repeated for credit once.
The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on studio projects of mutual interest.

courseTitle: Tutorial Work in Special Studio Topics
courseDescription: Independent investigation of a subject to be selected under the advisement of the instructor.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Independent investigation of a subject, critical evaluation of information
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Under advisement of the instructor, project management

courseDescription: A structured work experience involving aspects of art, design or craft; film or video making; and/or museum/gallery work.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with team members and clients
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Creative problem-solving in art and design projects
Critical evaluation of artistic concepts and techniques

courseTitle: Graduate Seminar: Special Topics in Contemporary Art
courseDescription: Topics to be specified in the class schedule.  Intensive critical investigations of selected aspects of the visual arts which focus on the role of the artist in contemporary urban society.  May be repeated for credit as topics vary.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Critique and feedback in art discussions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpretation of visual symbolism and themes

courseDescription: Supervised individual inquiry in specific studio projects relating to the areas of major interest.
Supervised individual inquiry in specific studio projects relating to the areas of major interest.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective presentation skills for studio projects
Clear communication of project goals and progress
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in decision-making for project direction

courseDescription: Intern experiences in museums, community centers and arts programs, teaching assistantships, special apprenticeships, and field projects under the supervision of graduate faculty.  Required of all M.F.A. candidates.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing creative solutions for art projects

courseDescription: Required of M.F.A. candidates.  Course requirements to be determined by the student's advisory committee.  Final grade to be determined by the student's thesis review committee.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting artwork effectively, Communicating artistic vision to audience, Collaborating with review committee
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of art pieces, Problem-solving in artistic presentation, Analyzing feedback from committee
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning exhibition logistics, Leading exhibition setup and coordination, Managing timeline for thesis completion

courseDescription: Studio work in preparation for required graduate exhibition.  Public exhibition to be approved by the student's advisory committee and must be accompanied by final review.  Documentation may be required.  Required of all M.A. and M.F.A.  candidates.  Final grade to be determined by the student's thesis review committee.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting documentation to thesis review committee

courseDescription: Supervised individual inquiry in specific studio projects relating to areas of major interest.  Individual studio spaces will be assigned.
Supervised individual inquiry in specific studio projects relating to areas of major interest.  Individual studio spaces will be assigned.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with peers on studio projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of studio project components
Identifying and resolving technical issues in project development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management of individual studio projects

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course doctoral students may take to maintain active status after successfully passing the candidacy examination.  All doctoral students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour every semester until their graduation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Maintaining active status in course registration
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with faculty and advisors
Building a support network within the program
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Strategizing course selection for academic progress
Troubleshooting issues related to course requirements
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Time management for balancing course workload
